questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is an example of disability limitation for polio?

options.a: Polio immunization drives for infants to reduce the occurence.
options.b: Arranging for schooling for a child suffering from residual polio paralysis.
options.c: Resting the limbs affected by polio in neutral position.
options.d: Providing calipers for walking to patients affected by polio.

questions.explanation:
Resting the limbs affected by polio in a neutral position is an example of disability limitation. It is 
an intervention done to either halt or prevent the transition of the disease process from 
impairment to handicap. Rehabilitation has been defined as the use of medical, social, educational, and vocational 
measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability. Like 
providing calipers for walking to patients and arranging schooling after being affected by polio. Immunization drives are examples of specific protection.

questions.question:
Question 2: A person is involved in unsafe sexual practices. Which of the following viruses is least likely to 
get transmitted via this route?
questions.explanation:
Hepatitis E has feco-oral or waterborne transmission. It does not transmit sexually. Transmission 
of Hepatitis A, C, and D can occur sexually. Transmission of the hepatitis A virus can occur from any sexual activity with an infected person 
and is not limited to fecal-oral contact. People who are sexually active are considered at risk for 
hepatitis A if they are MSM, live with or are having sex with an infected person, or inject drugs.

questions.question: Question 3: For how long is Hepatitis A excreted in the feces?

options.a: One week before the symptoms appear
options.b: Two weeks after the symptoms appear
options.c: Two weeks before the symptoms and two weeks thereafter
options.d: One week before the symptoms and one week thereafter

questions.explanation:
HAV is excreted in the feces for about 2 weeks before the onset of jaundice and for up to 2 weeks 
thereafter. The risk of transmitting is greatest at 2 weeks before to 1 week after the onset of jaundice.

questions.question:
Question 4: An intern sustains a needlestick injury while drawing blood from a Hepatitis B positive 
patient. Assuming he has been infected, which among the following will be the first to rise?
questions.explanation:
253 
Sold by @itachibot HbsAg is the first serological marker to be detected in Hepatitis B infection.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 30-year-old pregnant woman is rushed to the hospital with labor pains at 34 weeks of 
gestation. She did not attend any prior antenatal visits. On further evaluation, she is found to 
be positive for HbsAg. Which of the following should be administered to the newborn after 
delivery?

options.d: Immunoglobulin, followed by vaccine 1 month later

questions.explanation:
The simultaneous administration of hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and hepatitis B vaccine is 
more efficacious than HBIG alone for the prevention of the carrier state in newborn babies of 
HBV-positive mothers. HBIG does not interfere with the antibody response to the hepatitis B vaccine. This combined 
procedure is ideal both for postexposure prophylaxis of persons accidentally exposed to blood 
known to contain hepatitis B virus and for the prevention of the carrier state in the newborn 
babies of carrier mothers. HBIG (0.05–0.07 mL/kg) IM • As early as possible, preferably within 24 hours of exposure Hepatitis B vaccine (20 mcg/1.0 mL), IM • 1st dose: within 7 days of exposure • 2nd and 3rd dose: at one and six months, respectively

questions.question: Question 6: HCV screening is done for which of the following people?
questions.explanation:
Patients with a history of IV drug abuse, HIV, and a history of blood transfusion 32 years ago are 
screened for HCV. Since the screening of blood for Hepatitis C was started after 1˜˜2, hence people who have 
received a blood transfusion before 1˜˜2 (in this MC›, the year is 1˜˜2 in point 3) have to be 
screened. HCV screening is done for people who may be at risk for infection. These include: • People who received blood, blood products, or organs before screening for hepatitis C virus was 
implemented • Current or former injecting drug users • People on long-term hemodialysis • Health-care workers • People living with HIV • People with abnormal liver tests or liver disease • Infants born to infected mothers.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements is false about Rotavirus?

options.a: Severe rotavirus infections are limited to children aged 5-7 years.
options.b: Rotavirus is shed in high concentrations for several days in the stools and vomit of infected
options.c: Rotavirus diarrhoea increases in frequency during drier, cooler months.
options.d: Clean water supplies and good hygiene are unlikely to have a substantial effect on viral

questions.explanation:
254 
Sold by @itachibot Severe rotavirus gastroenteritis is largely limited to children aged 6-24 months, not 5-7 years. Rotavirus is the leading cause of severe, dehydrating diarrhea in children aged <5 years 
globally. In developing countries, 75% of the children acquire their first rotavirus infection in the 
first 12 months. The universal occurrence of rotavirus infections shows that clean water supply and good hygiene 
are unlikely to have a substantial effect on virus transmission. In tropical areas, rotavirus diarrhea 
occurs throughout the year, increasing in frequency in drier, cooler climates. Transmission is through the feco-oral route, person-to-person contact, or indirectly through 
fomites. Infected individuals shed very high concentrations of the virus for many days in their 
stool and vomit.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following statements is false for carriers of cholera?

options.a: A convalescent carrier may continue to excrete vibrios for 2-3 weeks.
options.c: The gall bladder is infected in chronic carriers.
options.d: The antibody titres of a contact carrier is normal while the stool culture is positive.

questions.explanation:
The antibody titers of all carriers are risen and positive till the person harbors the organism. A cholera carrier is defined as an apparently healthy person excreting V.cholerae O1 in stools. 
Selective media and enrichment is needed for their diagnosis. In cholera, 4 types of carriers are 
described. • Incubatory/Pre-Clinical carriers: The duration of carrier state is 1-5 days (incubation period). 
They present with symptoms later. 255 
Sold by @itachibot • Convalescent carriers: Recovered from an attack of cholera, continues to excrete vibrios for 2-3 
weeks, due to ineffective antibiotic treatment. • Contact/Health carrier: Due to subclinical infection contracted through a case or an infected 
environment, may excrete for 10 days. • Chronic carriers: Gallbladder is infected, duration may be as long as 10 years.

questions.question: Question 10: A convalescent carrier of cholera will remain infectious for how many days after recovery?
questions.explanation:
A convalescent carrier of cholera will remain infectious for 14-21 days after recovery. This type of carrier continues to excrete vibrios after being recovered from an attack of cholera. It 
is seen due to ineffective antibiotic treatment. These carriers can often become chronic or 
long-term carriers.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following guidelines will you follow to treat a child diagnosed with cholera?

options.b: A cardiotonic should be added if shock persists even after treating with iv fluids.
options.c: If the diarrhoea persists after 48 hours of treatment, suspect resistance.
options.d: Antidiarrheals and antiemetics should be started.

questions.explanation:
In patients with cholera, if diarrhea persists after 48 hours of antibiotic therapy, resistance to the 
antibiotic should be suspected. Treatment for cholera: • Rehydration therapy - is started immediately, either oral or intravenous. 256 
Sold by @itachibot • Antibiotic therapy - As soon as vomiting has stopped (usually after 3-4 hours of rehydration). 
Fluoroquinolones, tetracycline, azithromycin, ampicillin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are 
commonly used. • Shock in diarrhea must be corrected by intravenous fluids only. Antidiarrhoeals, cardiotonics, antiemetics, antispasmodics, and corticosteroids are not used.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 36-year-old man is diagnosed with cholera. Which of the following drug would you 
prescribe to his family members to prevent the spread of the disease?
questions.explanation:
Tetracycline is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of cholera. It should be given for: • Adults - a 3-day period in a twice-daily dose of 500mg • Children (4-13 years) - 125mg • Children (0-3 years) - 50mg Alternatively, the long-acting tetracycline (doxycycline) may be used for chemoprophylaxis, if the 
prevailing strains are not resistant. A single oral dose of doxycycline (300 mg for adults and 6 
mg/kg for children under 15 years) has proved to be effective. Chemoprophylaxis is advised only for household contacts or a closed community in which cholera 
has occurred.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is the most effective prophylactic measure against cholera?
questions.explanation: The most important effective measure against cholera is health education. The prophylactic measures against cholera include: • Health education • Food hygiene practices • Hand washing practices after defecation • Drinking safe water • Knowledge about ORS

questions.question:
Question 15: You are a medical officer posted in a village 'X'. The village has been affected by the epidemic 
of cholera. What is the first step that should be taken to decrease the incidence of the 
disease?

options.b: Cholera vaccination to all uninfected individuals
options.d: Treat everyone in the village with tetracycline

questions.explanation:
Safe water supply and sanitation is the first step to be taken to decrease the incidence of cholera. Steps taken to decrease the incidence of cholera include: • Safe water supply • Excreta disposal 257 
Sold by @itachibot • Food sanitation • Disinfection • Early case detection Cholera Vaccines: available in oral forms • Dukoral • Sanchol and mORCVAX • Euvichol • Vaxchora • CVD103-HgR - no longer produced Sanchol and Euvichol are available for mass vaccination campaigns. The campaigns have been 
implemented in areas experiencing an outbreak, in areas at heightened vulnerability during 
humanitarian crises, and among populations living in highly endemic areas, known as hotspots. Vaxchora is given for adults (18 – 64 years) who are traveling to an area of active cholera 
transmission, at least 10 days before the trip. Mass chemoprophylaxis is not recommended for the control of cholera. This is because the drug's 
effect is only short-lived (a few days). Moreover, for preventing 1 case of cholera, around 10,000 
individuals must be given the drug. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for only household 
contacts of confirmed cases with tetracycline.

questions.question:
Question 16: In the ward, a patient with cholera soils the bed with stools. Which chemical should be used 
to disinfect the bed?
questions.explanation:
The most effective disinfectant for cholera stool is a coal tar disinfectant with Riedel-Walker (RW) 
coefficient of >10 such as cresol. Bleaching powder, if used, should be of good quality. For disinfection, attention should be paid to the following: patient's stools and vomit; clothes and 
other contaminated personal items; the latrine, the patient's house, and neighborhood.

questions.question:
Question 17: Cholera is a notifiable disease locally and nationally. Which of the following statements is 
true regarding the international health regulations for the notification of Cholera?

options.a: Cholera is notifiable to the WHO by the National Government within 72 hours of its occurence.
options.b: The number of cases and deaths are to be reported daily and weekly till the area is declared free
options.c: An area is declared free of cholera when 1 month has elapsed since the last case.
options.d: Mass chemoprophylaxis must be initiated immediately.

questions.explanation:
The number of cases and deaths due to cholera are to be reported daily and weekly till the area is 
declared free of cholera. International health regulations for the notification of Cholera: • Cholera is notifiable to the WHO by the National Government within 24 hours of its occurrence. • The number of cases and deaths due to cholera are to be reported daily and weekly till the area is 
declared free of cholera. • When twice the incubation period (5 days) i.e. 10 days has elapsed since the death, recovery, or 
isolation of the last case, an area is declared free of cholera. 258 
Sold by @itachibot • Mass prophylaxis is not advised in cholera, as it fails to stop the spread of the disease. 
Chemoprophylaxis is only advised for household contacts or a closed community.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 5-year-old boy has had 15 episodes of loose stools in the last 24 hours and vomited twice in 
the last 4 hours. The child is restless and has sunken eyes. On examination, he is irritable but 
is drinking fluids. What is the optimal therapy for the child?

options.c: Intravenous fluid initially for 4 hours followed by oral fluids

questions.explanation:
Oral rehydration therapy is the optimal therapy to treat acute diarrheas in some 
dehydration patients. Recommended formulation: Reduced osmolarity ORS solution, which has a reduced 
concentration of sodium (75 mmol/liter) and glucose (75 mmol/liter). It helps in reducing the 
adverse effect of hypertonicity on net fluid absorption. According to IMNCI guidelines, irritable child who is able to drink fluids come under some 
dehydration category.

questions.question:
Question 19: A mother brings her child with complaints of acute diarrhea. After an initial assessment, you 
diagnose that the child has some dehydration. You counsel the mother to give ORS. After how 
many hours shall she be advised to discard the old solution and prepare a new one? 248 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The freshly prepared ORS should not be used after 24 hours. Guidelines for administering ORS: • After each loose stool, give: • Children <2 years of age - 50-100 ml (a quarter to half a large cup) of fluid • Children 2 to 10 years - 100-200 ml (a half to one large cup) • Older children and adults - as much fluid as they want • For children <2 years, give a teaspoon every 1 to 2 minutes and offer frequent sips out of a cup 
for older children. Try to give the estimated required amount within a 4-hour period. • If the child vomits, wait for 10 minutes, then give a spoonful every 2 to 3 minutes. 259 
Sold by @itachibot • If the child wants to drink more ORS solution than the estimated amount and does not vomit, 
there is no harm in feeding him/her more. • If the child is breastfeeding, continue breastfeeding with ORS solution.

questions.question: Question 22: Which among the following home remedies are not advised for a child with diarrhea?

options.a: A mixture of 1 teaspoon of salt and 6 teaspoons of sugar in 1 L of drinking water
options.b: Unsalted water in which a cereal has been cooked
options.d: Soup with 3g/litre salt added to it

questions.explanation:
Salted water in which cereal has been cooked can be given to a child with diarrhoea. If the WHO ORS mixture is not available, a simple mixture of 1 teaspoon of salt and 6 teaspoons 
of sugar must be dissolved in 1 L of drinking water and given to the child. Fluids that do not contain salt in water, for eg: rice water, unsalted soup, yoghurt drinks, green 
coconut water, etc, must not be given. 3g/litre of salt must be added to such drinks before giving it 
to the child with diarrhoea. The infant's usual diet of cereals, vegetables and other foods should be continued and never be 
diluted. The child should be given as much nutrient-rich food as acceptable. Avoid the following: • Sweetened drinks with sugar, like commercial fruit juices and sweetened tea, as they lead to 
osmotic diarrhoea and hypernatremia. • Fluids with a stimulant and purgative effect like coffee and medicinal tea infusions.

questions.question:
Question 23: 249 
Sold by @itachibot A child with severe dehydration is being treated with intravenous fluids for the past 2 hours. 
Which of the following will be used as an early indicator for adequate rehydration?
questions.explanation:
Skin elasticity and pulse strength are the most helpful indicators for adequate intravenous 
rehydration. 261 
Sold by @itachibot The urine output may be unchanged even after 3-4 hours of adequate rehydration. Hence, it 
cannot be a criterion for continuous examination. The initial rehydration must be fast until an easily palpable pulse is present. Reassess the patient 
every 1-2 hours. After 1-2 liters of fluid have been infused, the drip should be slowed down till the blood pressure 
and pulse return to normal. Rehydration must be continued otherwise till all signs of dehydration 
have disappeared. ORS should be given when the patient can drink oral fluids. Puffy eyelids are a sign of excess rehydration and intravenous fluids must be stopped when it 
occurs.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 15-year-old boy is referred from a sub-center due to a feeble pulse and low BP. The patient 
has had diarrhea for 2 days. He has sunken eyes and is lethargic. On examination, BP is 
˜0/60 mmHg. Which of the following fluids cannot be used for resuscitation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
This patient has severe dehydration which is treated by giving IV fluids. Plain glucose and 
dextrose solutions should not be used as they worsen the hyperosmolar state. Intravenous rehydration: Used for initial rehydration for patients in shock or those who are 
unable to drink. • Ringer's lactate solution/Hartmann's solution - Used for injection. Best commercially available 
solution. • Diarrhea treatment solution- Recommended as an ideal polyelectrolyte solution for intravenous 
infusion. • Normal saline- Used if nothing else is available. It is the poorest fluid, as it does not correct the 
acidosis and will not replace the potassium losses.

questions.question: Question 25: What is the recommended dosage for zinc supplements in children with diarrhea?

options.a: 20 mg of zinc daily for infants < 12 months of age for 10-14 days
options.b: 20 mg of zinc for children > 6 months of age for 7 days
options.c: 10 mg of zinc for children > 12 months of age for 20 days
options.d: 10 mg of zinc for children < 6 months of age for 10-14 days

questions.explanation:
According to WHO and UNICEF, 10 mg of zinc is given to infants < 6 months of age for 10-14 
days. 20 mg of Zinc is given to infants > 6 months of age for 10-14 days during an episode of acute 
diarrhoea. This is done to reduce the duration and severity of the episode and prevent recurrence 
in the following months. Intensified Diarrhea Control Fortnight : The goal is to attain zero child deaths due to childhood 
diarrhea. The overall objective of IDCF is to ensure high coverage of ORS and Zinc use rates in 
children with diarrhoea. It also complements awareness activities (including Swachh) for 
prevention and management of diarrhoea in under-five children.

questions.question: Question 26: For a child with SAM, what should be the sodium content of his rehydration fluid?

(45mmol/L) and a higher amount of potassium (40 mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS. ReSoMal is used in in-patient centers for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition 
(SAM). It is useful in correcting hypokalemia, and in lowering the risks of excess sodium and/or

questions.question: Question 27: What is the average incubation period of typhoid fever?
questions.explanation: The average incubation period of typhoid is 10-14 days. However, it can vary from 3 days to 3 weeks depending on the dose of bacilli ingested.

questions.question:
Question 28: In a boys hostel, there has been an outbreak of typhoid. The hostel cook is identified as the 
carrier of the disease. Which is true among the following statements regarding her condition?

options.a: Gallbladder is usually not involved in carrier state
options.b: Chronic carriers are those who excrete the bacilli for more than a year
options.c: Tetracycline is the drug of choice for carriers
options.d: To treat the carrier state, treatment should be given for 4 weeks

questions.explanation:
Chronic carriers of typhoid are those who excrete the bacilli for more than a year. Convalescent carriers excrete bacilli for 6-8 weeks and chronic carriers excrete for more than a 
year. The carrier rate in females is higher. Gallbladder and biliary tract are affected. To treat the carrier state, an intensive course of ampicillin or amoxicillin (4-6 g a day) together 
with Probenecid (2 g/day) for 6 weeks is given. Cholecystectomy with concomitant ampicillin 
therapy is the most successful treatment for the carrier state.

questions.question: Question 29: In which of the following patients can the Ty21a vaccine be administered?

options.a: A 50-year-old HIV patient who is asymptomatic with CD4+ count 240/mm3
options.b: A 42-year-old patient with fever and cough for 3 days
options.d: A 64-years-old alcoholic on colchicine therapy for acute gout

questions.explanation:
263 
Sold by @itachibot Ty21a vaccine can be administered in an HIV-positive asymptomatic patient as long as the CD4+ 
count is >200/ cubic mm. Ty21a is an oral vaccine for individuals 5 years of age. It is given in 3 doses on the 1st, 3rd, and 
5th day. Repeat every 3 years for endemic areas, and every year for traveling individuals. It is not recommended in: • Patients on antimitotic drugs and immunosuppressants • Acute febrile illness • Acute intestinal infestation Proguanil and antibacterial drugs should be stopped from 3 days before to 3 days after the 
vaccine.

questions.question: Question 30: Which of the following statements is false regarding dracunculiasis?

options.b: Niridazole prevents transmission of the disease.
options.c: The disease is limited to tropical and subtropical regions.
options.d: No animal reservoir has been proved.

questions.explanation:
Niridazole does not prevent transmission of the disease. Dracunculiasis is treated by removing the worm by sequentially rolling them out over a small 
stick. Wet compresses may relieve discomfort. Occlusive dressings limit shedding of infectious 
larvae. Metronidazole and mebendazole are used to limit inflammation and facilitate worm removal. Dracunculiasis or Guinea-worm disease is amenable to eradication. The eradication strategy 
comprises the following elements : • Provision of safe drinking water. • Control of cyclops. • Health education regarding drinking boiled water. • Surveillance: Active search for new cases.

questions.question: Question 31: Which of the following statements is false about hookworms?
questions.explanation:
The blood loss due to Ancylostoma (0.2 ml/day) is more compared to Necatur americanus 
(0.03ml/day) Malnutrition is a predisposing factor. The chronic disabling disease does not occur in individuals 
who are well-nourished and whose iron intake is adequate. Chandler's index is used to identify importance of hookworm infestation as a public health 
problem. It is calculated as average number of hookworm eggs/gram of stool. • <200: no significance • 200-250: the potential danger • 250-300: minor public health problem 264 
Sold by @itachibot • >300: major public health problem Hookworm inection causes chronic blood loss and depletion of body's iron stores leading to iron 
deficiency anemia. This in pregnant women can lead to abortions, stillbirth and low birth weight 
babies. 265 
Sold by @itachibot Arthropod-Borne Infections
